Posts.Content: Oct 14, 2008 09:38AM CAZ wrote: Caroline, I by no means have a comprehensive list, but here are a few thoughts IMHO: Have a second opinion at a breast center on the histopathology slides. A breast center coordinates each step and saves you the nightmare of schlepping your records and waiting between steps. Especially if you had positive nodes, you'll want to know what kind of chemo and radiation.  The receptors on the cells help to decide if hormonal therapy is indicated. Will they be doing lumpectomy VS mastectomy. If you'll be having a mastectomy, you'll have to consider unilateral versus bilateral and the type of reconstruction if you so choose.  Some reconstructions require a certain body type, and some can require a longer recovery to full strength. Take a family member or tape recorder to the appointment.   There is a lot to digest. Best of luck.  I know it is scary, but once you have a plan of attack, it gets better. Keep us posted, Carol(AZ)

Posts.Content: Apr 9, 2009 05:51PM CAZ wrote: Hi Geena, We're all a little different, but I'll share my experience with the same procedure.  My husband is extremely squeamish.  I was able to take care of stripping the drain tubes and washing my hair by myself.  They let me shower after 24 hrs at home even with drains.  I put an ice chest on a nonslip pad in the shower so I could sit.  It worked well.  It would be nice if someone could come do your laundry every few days since pulling wet clothes out of the machine would hurt.  Sleeping in a recliner as rayhope said was best for the first few days until I could roll on my side to lift myself out of bed. If your friends could take turns calling you for the first week, I think you'll be fine.  While it was very nice to have my husband around, I could have made it without him if I had to. One more note, then less active you are, the sooner the drains can come out, so don't try to do too much on your own. Best of luck, Carol(AZ)

Posts.Content: Jun 17, 2008 12:10PM CAZ wrote: With DCIS, I think it would be a new primary lesion.   So very sorry.  It increases the risk in both breasts.  A primary mass shouldn't spread to the other breast since spread is through lymphatics.  A new primary is actually better news than metastasis (I know that is cold comfort).  Sorry you have to go through it again. Posts.Content: Jun 20, 2008 01:52PM CAZ wrote: Hi Estepp, Sorry you're going through this.  The wait can be unbearable.  What kind of results are you expecting?  Biopsy with SNB? Needle aspirate? etc There are a few tests they do on the cancer cells to determine what kind of receptors it may have.  If it is not a very aggressive lesion (eg ADH), they have large clean margins, and the lymph nodes are clean, you may not need anything further.  Unfortunately, until the results are back, you won't know what the recommendations will be.  Remember, most masses are benign anyway.  Hang in there. Carol(AZ)

Posts.Content: Mar 26, 2009 12:04PM CAZ wrote: I went home by 5pm the following day (BLM w/ tissue expanders).  I had an On Q pain ball that irrigated the surgery site with local anesthetic for about 3 days.  I could have managed by myself, but certainly appreciated being waited on by my DH.  Put everything within waist to shoulder height.  Stock up on easy to reheat comfort food.  You can't drive while you're on prescription pain meds.  I took them for about a week.  Sitting up from a prone position was the hardest for me.  I had to roll to my side and push up on an elbow.  Overall, it wasn't as bad as I had feared. Posts.Content: Jun 16, 2008 04:51PM CAZ wrote: Hey 2pompom, Waiting is the pits.  Your mind wanders from guilt to hopeless and back again.  Don't beat yourself up.  There aren't many of us who haven't written off a lump at one time or another.  My first ultrasound confirmed multiple cysts even though I could only feel one.  My PCP at the time was an a**.  He wouldn't let them to an ultrasound right after the mammogram until he saw the written report.  By that time, I had to wait another month to get into an ultrasound.  When I called his office to confirm he got the mammogram report, they said he was just waiting on the US report. I explained in octaves and volumes well beyond my normal reach, that he had not approved the ultrasound yet. Make sure you have a doctor and facility you trust, then you know you'll get the news when they have it. We'll be waiting with you. Carol(AZ)
